API Reference¶

magnav Module¶

Main module for MagNavPy, translated from MagNav.jl.

This module provides core data structures, constants, utility functions, and access to datasets for magnetic navigation.

magnavpy.magnav.get_cached_map(maps: List[MapS] | MapS, fallback: MapS = MapS(info='null', lat=array([], dtype=float64), lon=array([], dtype=float64), alt=array([], dtype=float64), map=array([], dtype=float64), xx=array([], dtype=float64), yy=array([], dtype=float64)), dz: int | float = 100) → MapCache[source]¶

Retrieves or creates a cached map object.

Parameters:

  • maps – A list of MapS objects or a single MapS object to use as the base map(s).

  • fallback – An optional MapS object to use as a fallback if no suitable map is found in maps. Defaults to MAP_S_NULL.

  • dz – The altitude discretization for the cache [m].

Returns:

A MapCache object containing the interpolated maps.

magnavpy.magnav.run_filt(ins: INS, xyz: XYZ0 | XYZ1 | XYZ20 | XYZ21, filter_params: Any, mag_map: MapS = MapS(info='null', lat=array([], dtype=float64), lon=array([], dtype=float64), alt=array([], dtype=float64), map=array([], dtype=float64), xx=array([], dtype=float64), yy=array([], dtype=float64)), temp_params: TempParams = None) → FILTres[source]¶

Runs the specified filter (Extended Kalman Filter or Neural EKF for now) and returns its results.

Parameters:

  • ins – INS data.

  • xyz – Flight data (XYZ0, XYZ1, XYZ20, or XYZ21).

  • filter_params – Filter parameters (e.g., EKF_RT).

  • mag_map – A MapS object representing the magnetic anomaly map. Defaults to MAP_S_NULL.

  • temp_params – (Optional) Temperature compensation parameters.

Returns:

A FILTres object containing the filter results.

class magnavpy.compensation.M1Struct(m: Sequential)[source]¶

Bases: Module

forward(x: Tensor) → Tensor[source]¶

Define the computation performed at every call.

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

class magnavpy.compensation.NNCompParams(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: CompParams

magnavpy.compensation.TL_mat2vec(TL_coef_p: ndarray, TL_coef_i_mat: ndarray, TL_coef_e_mat: ndarray, terms: List[str], Bt_scale: float = 50000.0) → ndarray[source]¶

Extract the vector form of Tolles-Lawson coefficients from the matrix form.

Parameters:

  • TL_coef_p – length-3 vector of permanent field coefficients

  • TL_coef_i_mat – 3x3 symmetric matrix of induced field coefficients, denormalized

  • TL_coef_e_mat – 3x3 matrix of eddy current coefficients, denormalized

  • terms – Tolles-Lawson terms used {‘permanent’,’induced’,’eddy’, …}

  • Bt_scale – (optional) scaling factor for induced & eddy current terms [nT]

Returns:

Tolles-Lawson coefficients as a single vector

Return type:

TL_coef

magnavpy.compensation.TL_vec2mat(TL_coef: ndarray, terms: List[str], Bt_scale: float = 50000.0) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]¶

Extract the matrix form of Tolles-Lawson coefficients from the vector form.

Parameters:

  • TL_coef – Tolles-Lawson coefficients (must include ‘permanent’ & ‘induced’)

  • terms – Tolles-Lawson terms used {‘permanent’,’induced’,’eddy’, …}

  • Bt_scale – (optional) scaling factor for induced & eddy current terms [nT]

Returns:

length-3 vector of permanent field coefficients TL_coef_i: 3x3 symmetric matrix of induced field coefficients, denormalized TL_coef_e: 3x3 matrix of eddy current coefficients, denormalized

Return type:

TL_coef_p

magnavpy.compensation.TL_vec_split(TL_coef: ndarray, terms: List[str]) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]¶

Internal helper function to separate Tolles-Lawson coefficients from a single vector to individual permanent, induced, & eddy current coefficient vectors.

Parameters:

  • TL_coef – Tolles-Lawson coefficients (must include ‘permanent’ & ‘induced’)

  • terms – Tolles-Lawson terms used {‘permanent’,’induced’,’eddy’, ‘p’,’i’,’e’, ‘permanent3’, ‘p3’, ‘induced6’, ‘i6’, ‘induced5’, ‘i5’, ‘induced3’, ‘i3’, ‘eddy9’, ‘e9’, ‘eddy8’, ‘e8’, ‘eddy3’, ‘e3’}

Returns:

length-3 vector of permanent field coefficients TL_i: length-3, 5, or 6 vector of induced field coefficients TL_e: length-0, 3, 8, or 9 vector of eddy current coefficients

Return type:

TL_p

magnavpy.compensation.elasticnet_fit(x: ndarray, y: ndarray, alpha: float = 0.99, no_norm: ndarray | None = None, lambda_val: float = -1.0, data_norms_in: Tuple | None = None, l_segs: List[int] | None = None, silent: bool = False) → Tuple[Tuple[ndarray, float], Tuple, ndarray, ndarray][source]¶

Fit an elastic net (ridge regression and/or Lasso) model to data.

Parameters:

  • x – N x Nf data matrix (Nf is number of features)

  • y – length-N target vector

  • alpha – (optional) ElasticNet mixing parameter, with 0 <= alpha <= 1. alpha=0 is L2 penalty (Ridge), alpha=1 is L1 penalty (Lasso).

  • no_norm – (optional) length-Nf Boolean indices of features to not be normalized

  • lambda_val – (optional) elastic net regularization strength. If -1, determine with cross-validation.

  • data_norms_in – (optional) length-4 tuple of data normalizations, (x_bias,x_scale,y_bias,y_scale)

  • l_segs – (optional) length-N_lines vector of lengths of lines, sum(l_segs) = N

  • silent – (optional) if true, no print outs

Returns:

length-2 tuple of elastic net model, (length-Nf coefficients, bias) data_norms_out: length-4 tuple of data normalizations, (x_bias,x_scale,y_bias,y_scale) y_hat: length-N prediction vector err: length-N mean-corrected (per line) error

Return type:

model

Placeholder for calculating error, possibly mean-corrected per segment.

magnavpy.compensation.get_TL_aircraft_vec(B_vec: ndarray, B_vec_dot: ndarray, TL_coef_p: ndarray, TL_coef_i_mat: ndarray, TL_coef_e_mat: ndarray | None, return_parts: bool = False) → ndarray | Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]¶

Calculates the Tolles-Lawson aircraft vector field.

Parameters:

  • B_vec – 3xN matrix of vector magnetometer measurements

  • B_vec_dot – 3xN matrix of vector magnetometer measurement derivatives

  • TL_coef_p – length-3 vector of permanent field coefficients

  • TL_coef_i_mat – 3x3 symmetric matrix of induced field coefficients, denormalized

  • TL_coef_e_mat – 3x3 matrix of eddy current coefficients, denormalized, or None/empty

  • return_parts – (optional) if true, also return TL_perm, TL_induced, & TL_eddy

Returns:

3xN matrix of TL aircraft vector field (if return_parts): TL_perm, TL_induced, TL_eddy

Return type:

TL_aircraft

magnavpy.compensation.get_curriculum_ind(TL_diff: ndarray, N_sigma: float = 1.0) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]¶

Internal helper function to get indices for curriculum learning. Curriculum learning (Tolles-Lawson) indices are those within N_sigma of the mean, and neural network indices are those outside of it (i.e., outliers).

Parameters:

  • TL_diff – Difference of TL model to ground truth.

  • N_sigma – (optional) Standard deviation threshold.

Returns:

Indices for curriculum learning (within N_sigma), boolean array. ind_nn: Indices for training the neural network (outside N_sigma), boolean array.

Return type:

ind_cur

magnavpy.compensation.get_temporal_data(x_norm: ndarray, l_segs: List[int], l_window: int) → ndarray[source]¶

Internal helper function to create windowed sequence temporal data from original data. Adds padding to beginning of data. Uses line lengths to avoid windowing across lines, but (ad hoc) checks if any lines may be sequential.

Parameters:

  • x_norm – Nf x N normalized data matrix (Nf is number of features)

  • l_segs – length-N_lines vector of lengths of lines, sum(l_segs) = N

  • l_window – temporal window length

Returns:

Nf x l_window x N normalized data matrix, windowed
(Note: PyTorch LSTMs/Transformers often expect seq_len first or batch first,

so further permutation might be needed depending on the model layer)

Return type:

x_w

magnavpy.compensation.linear_fit(x: ndarray, y: ndarray, no_norm: ndarray | None = None, trim: int = 0, lambda_ridge: float = 0.0, norm_type_x: str = 'none', norm_type_y: str = 'none', data_norms_in: Tuple | None = None, l_segs: List[int] | None = None, silent: bool = False) → Tuple[Tuple[ndarray, float], Tuple, ndarray, ndarray][source]¶

Fit a linear regression model to data.

Parameters:

  • x – N x Nf data matrix (Nf is number of features)

  • y – length-N target vector

  • no_norm – (optional) length-Nf Boolean indices of features to not be normalized

  • trim – (optional) number of elements to trim from each segment (e.g., due to bpf)

  • lambda_ridge – (optional) ridge parameter

  • norm_type_x – (optional) normalization for x data matrix

  • norm_type_y – (optional) normalization for y target vector

  • data_norms_in – (optional) length-4 tuple of data normalizations, (x_bias,x_scale,y_bias,y_scale)

  • l_segs – (optional) length-N_lines vector of lengths of lines, sum(l_segs) = N

  • silent – (optional) if true, no print outs

Returns:

length-2 tuple of linear regression model, (length-Nf coefficients, bias=0.0) data_norms_out: length-4 tuple of data normalizations, (x_bias,x_scale,y_bias,y_scale) y_hat: length-N prediction vector err: length-N mean-corrected (per line) error

Return type:

model

magnavpy.compensation.linear_fwd(x_in: ndarray, data_norms_or_y_bias: Tuple | float | ndarray, model_or_y_scale: Tuple[ndarray, float] | float | ndarray, model_if_normalized: Tuple[ndarray, float] | None = None) → ndarray[source]¶

Forward pass of a linear model. This function handles two call signatures from Julia via dispatch: 1. linear_fwd(x_norm, y_bias, y_scale, model_tuple) 2. linear_fwd(x_raw, data_norms_tuple, model_tuple)

Parameters:

  • x_in (numpy.ndarray) – N x Nf data matrix (either normalized or raw)

  • data_norms_or_y_bias (Union[Tuple, float, numpy.ndarray]) – Either data_norms tuple (x_bias, x_scale, y_bias, y_scale) or y_bias directly.

  • model_or_y_scale (Union[Tuple[numpy.ndarray, float], float, numpy.ndarray]) – Either the model tuple (coeffs, bias_val) or y_scale directly.

  • model_if_normalized (Optional[Tuple[numpy.ndarray, float]]) – The model tuple, used if the first signature is matched.

Returns:

length-N prediction vector

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

magnavpy.compensation.plsr_fit(x: ndarray, y: ndarray, k: int | None = None, no_norm: ndarray | None = None, data_norms_in: Tuple | None = None, l_segs: List[int] | None = None, return_set: bool = False, silent: bool = False) → Tuple[Tuple[ndarray, float], Tuple, ndarray, ndarray] | ndarray[source]¶

Fit a multi-input, single-output (MISO for now) partial least squares regression (PLSR) model. Python translation of MagNav.jl’s plsr_fit. Note: The Julia version supports MIMO (Ny > 1), this Python version is simplified to MISO (Ny=1) for now, as y is typically a 1D vector in this context. If MIMO is needed, q_out and coef_set dimensions would need adjustment.

magnavpy.compensation.sparse_group_lasso(model: Module, alpha: float) → Tensor[source]¶

Computes the Sparse Group Lasso (SGL) penalty term for a PyTorch model. The penalty is calculated as: alpha * L1_norm + (1-alpha) * L2_norm_group_wise This function sums this term over all nn.Linear layers’ weights. The overall regularization strength (lambda_sgl) should be applied multiplicatively to the output of this function.

Parameters:

  • model (nn.Module) – The neural network model (typically an nn.Sequential containing nn.Linear layers).

  • alpha (float) – The mixing parameter between L1 and L2 norms. alpha=1 gives Lasso, alpha=0 gives Group Lasso (L2 on layer weights).

Returns:

The SGL penalty value (scalar tensor).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

magnavpy.compensation.unpack_data_norms(data_norms_tuple: Tuple) → Tuple[source]¶

rt_comp_main Module¶

tolles_lawson Module¶

Tolles-Lawson aeromagnetic compensation algorithm, translated from MagNav.jl.

magnavpy.tolles_lawson.create_TL_A(flux_or_Bx: MagV | ndarray, By: ndarray | None = None, Bz: ndarray | None = None, ind: ndarray | None = None, *, Bt: ndarray | None = None, terms: Sequence[Literal['permanent', 'p', 'permanent3', 'p3', 'induced', 'i', 'induced6', 'i6', 'induced5', 'i5', 'induced3', 'i3', 'eddy', 'e', 'eddy9', 'e9', 'eddy8', 'e8', 'eddy3', 'e3', 'fdm', 'f', 'fdm3', 'f3', 'bias', 'b']] = ('permanent', 'induced', 'eddy'), Bt_scale: float = 50000.0, return_B: bool = False) → ndarray | Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]¶

Create Tolles-Lawson A matrix. See _create_TL_A_components for details. Handles MagV input or Bx,By,Bz components.

magnavpy.tolles_lawson.create_TL_coef(flux_or_Bx: MagV | ndarray, arg2: ndarray, arg3: ndarray | None = None, B_scalar_for_bx_case: ndarray | None = None, *, Bt: ndarray | None = None, lambda_val: float = 0.0, terms: Sequence[Literal['permanent', 'p', 'permanent3', 'p3', 'induced', 'i', 'induced6', 'i6', 'induced5', 'i5', 'induced3', 'i3', 'eddy', 'e', 'eddy9', 'e9', 'eddy8', 'e8', 'eddy3', 'e3', 'fdm', 'f', 'fdm3', 'f3', 'bias', 'b']] = ('permanent', 'induced', 'eddy'), pass1: float = 0.1, pass2: float = 0.9, fs: float = 10.0, pole: int = 4, trim: int = 20, Bt_scale: float = 50000.0, return_var: bool = False) → ndarray | Tuple[ndarray, float][source]¶

Create Tolles-Lawson coefficients. See _create_TL_coef_components for details. Handles MagV input or Bx,By,Bz components.

Parameters:

  • flux_or_Bx – MagV object or Bx (x-component) as np.ndarray.

  • arg2 – If flux_or_Bx is MagV, this is B_scalar (scalar measurements). If flux_or_Bx is Bx (array), this is By (y-component).

  • arg3 – If flux_or_Bx is MagV, this is ind (selected indices, optional). If flux_or_Bx is Bx (array), this is Bz (z-component).

  • B_scalar_for_bx_case – Scalar measurements [nT]. Required if using Bx,By,Bz components.

  • follow) ((Keyword arguments)

magnavpy.tolles_lawson.fdm(x: ndarray, scheme: Literal['backward', 'forward', 'central', 'central2', 'backward2', 'forward2', 'fourth', 'central4'] = 'central') → ndarray[source]¶

Finite difference method (FDM) applied to x.

Parameters:

  • x – data vector

  • scheme – (optional) finite difference method scheme used - “backward”: 1st derivative 1st-order backward difference - “forward”: 1st derivative 1st-order forward difference - “central”: 1st derivative 2nd-order central difference (also “central2”) - “backward2”: 1st derivative 2nd-order backward difference - “forward2”: 1st derivative 2nd-order forward difference - “fourth”: 4th derivative central difference (also “central4”)

Returns:

Vector of finite differences (length of x)

magnavpy.tolles_lawson.get_TL_term_ind(term_to_find: str, current_terms: Sequence[str]) → ndarray[source]¶

Finds indices corresponding to term_to_find in a TL coefficient vector generated using current_terms.

magnavpy.plot_functions.plot_activation(activation_func_names=None, plot_deriv=False, show_plot=True, save_plot=False, plot_png='act_func.png')[source]¶

Plot activation function(s) or their derivative(s).

Parameters:

  • activation_func_names (list, optional) – activation function names (strings: ‘relu’, ‘sigmoid’, ‘swish’, ‘tanh’). Defaults to [‘relu’, ‘sigmoid’, ‘swish’, ‘tanh’].

  • plot_deriv (bool, optional) – if true, plot derivatives. Defaults to False.

  • show_plot (bool, optional) – if true, show plot. Defaults to True.

  • save_plot (bool, optional) – if true, save plot. Defaults to False.

  • plot_png (str, optional) – plot file name to save. Defaults to “act_func.png”.

Returns:

The plot figure.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

magnavpy.plot_functions.plot_basic(tt, y, ind=None, lab='', xlab='time [min]', ylab='', show_plot=True, save_plot=False, plot_png='data_vs_time.png')[source]¶

Plot data vs time.

Parameters:

  • tt (np.ndarray) – length-N time vector [s]

  • y (np.ndarray) – length-N data vector

  • ind (np.ndarray, optional) – boolean array for selected data indices. Defaults to all true.

  • lab (str, optional) – data (legend) label. Defaults to “”.

  • xlab (str, optional) – x-axis label. Defaults to “time [min]”.

  • ylab (str, optional) – y-axis label. Defaults to “”.

  • show_plot (bool, optional) – if true, show plot. Defaults to True.

  • save_plot (bool, optional) – if true, save plot as plot_png. Defaults to False.

  • plot_png (str, optional) – plot file name to save. Defaults to “data_vs_time.png”.

Returns:

The plot figure.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure
